organic_results.title: Evaluating the content of textbooks: Public interests and professional authority
organic_results.snippet: This article examines public and professional participation in a state-level textbook-selection process. It asserts that while centralized adoption provides a forum for citizens and interest groups to present competing cultural and symbolic claims, the input of these groups has a limited impact on professional educators, whose decisions reflect the dominance of technical priorities. Although instrumental objectives and loose control over ideological content enable the state apparatus to mediate competing claims, they preclude the …
